Instructions.text: Enrichment Ratio is a quick dive into the quality of your concentrate. It gives you a ratio between the amount of precious metal going in and the amount of precious metal going out.
It can be calculated by dividing a metal grade on the Concentrate stream by the grade of the same metal in the Feed stream.

In a flotation process that the precious metal is nickel, and the Feed Ni % is 2 while the Concentrate Ni % is 6, what would be the Enrichment Ratio?

 Enrichment ratio =
Concentrate Metal % / Feed Metal %

Check the Cu grade in the Feed and Concentrate streams and calculate the enrichment ratio. With the Froth Thickness set to '-10' set the Air Flow Rate from '2' to '4'. What happened to the Enrichment Ratio?

Correct. It means that the Cu grade, or quality of your concentrate, increased. That can't be a bad thing, right? But take a second look at the Concentrate stream. What happened to the flow rate, in other words, the amount being produced?
Enrichment Ratio, although a quick dive into the system grades, does not take quantity into consideration, unlike metal recovery.
Check out the Cu recovery graph in the Concentrate stream, for example. What happened to it?
Correct! Perhaps we should set the air and froth to their initial values (15 and -30). Well done!
